p: Yellow fever (YF) is an acute viral hemorrhagic disease which is currently endemic to ∼50 countries with ∼1 billion people living at risk of infection. Despite the availability of a highly efficient vaccine (YFV-17D; e.g., Stamaril), an estimated ∼0.2 million YFV infections with 29,000 to 60,000 deaths occur annually ( 5). Recent YFV outbreaks in Angola (2015-2016), the Democratic Republic of the Congo (2016), Brazil (2017), and Nigeria (2018) and a shortage of the YF vaccine supply raised serious concerns about the preparedness for future outbreaks ( 6, 7). Since the Aedes aegypti mosquito, the main YFV vector, is omnipresent in (sub)tropical Asia, YFV spillover to Asia and the establishment of epidemics involving urban transmission become increasingly realistic ( 8, 9).
